questions.text: A child is brought to the hospital with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor. The radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis

The diagnosis in this child with respiratory distress and biphasic stridor is acute laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The x-ray finding is the ‘steeple sign’ due to subglottic narrowing.

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months to 6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, and low-grade fever.

questions.text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby’s head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

6 months

Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.

The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

questions.text: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the following findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia The image shows a typical Down’s facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protruding tongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

questions.text: Rohit is brought to the pediatrician by his mother because of red-eye. He complains of blurring of vision and on examination, the pupil appears as shown in the picture. Which of the following subtype of JIA is associated with the highest risk for the ophthalmic complication noted in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ANA-positive oligoarthritis

The patient has red-eye and the blurring of vision along with the finding of the irregular pupil, which is suggestive of uveitis. ANA-positive oligoarthritis is associated with the highest risk for uveitis in patients with Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis.

The presence of a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) confers increased risk for uveitis in children with JIA and requires periodic slit-lamp examination every 3 months.

questions.text: A mother brings her 4-year-old child to the OPD. She says that the child has recurrent chest infections, easy fatiguability, and poor growth. You notice a limb abnormality as shown in the image below and find the given X-ray of the child’s arm in his medical history. Based on all the findings, you suspect a congenital heart disease. Which of the following conditions are you most likely to find on screening echocardiography?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Atrial septal defect

The X-ray of the upper limb shows radial ray defects (absent radius and thumb) and the family history of heart disease suggest a diagnosis of Holt-Oram syndrome (aka hand-heart syndrome). Out of all the syndromes associated with cardiac defects, HOLT-ORAM has the strongest familial tendency – it is inherited in an Autosomal dominant manner. Holt-Oram syndrome/cardiac limb syndrome is most commonly associated with atrial septal defect (ASD).

questions.text: Of the following, all are findings of the condition in the below chest x-ray except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right atrial enlargement

The given chest x-ray shows an egg-on-string appearance seen in the transposition of great arteries (TGA). Enlargement of the left atrium is seen in TGA, not the right atriurn.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Cri-du-chat syndrome

In the karyotype, there is a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5, which leads to Cri-du-chat syndrome. Partial aneuploidy occurs as a result of the breakdown of the chromosomes.

Cri-du-chat syndrome is a rare genetic disorder. Features of the condition are hypotonia, short stature, characteristic cry called a cat’s cry in the first few weeks of life, microcephaly with protruding metopic sutures, hypertelorism, bilateral epicanthic folds, high arched palate, flat nasal bridge, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A young girl was referred to the paediatrician with stage IV breast development and growth acceleration seen at the age of 5 years. Her estradiol concentrations were elevated. The sagittal MRI of the brain is as shown below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

GnRH agonists

A pedunculated mass in the floor of the 3rd ventricle as shown in the MRI, with elevated levels of estrogen is suggestive of a Hypothalamic Hamartoma, which is the most common brain lesion causing central precocious puberty and is treated with GnRH agonists

choices.text: It is a mitochondrial storage disorder

questions.text: An 8-year-old child has difficulty walking and getting up from a squatting position. A muscle biopsy was done and is as shown in the image. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Death occurs in 3rd decade

The clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing fatty replacement of muscle fibers are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Death in DMD occurs in the late teens and 20s (3rd decade).

DMD is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern. It is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is brought with 4 small, purplish, rubbery lesions on his back and arms. On examination, you note inguinal freckling and nodules on the iris as shown below. Which chromosome is involved in the syndrome described in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

17

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 1. The NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child comes with abdominal distension, a palpable mass, and gross hematuria. A biopsy of the mass shows the following picture. Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes in not associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy

The histopathological image shows the characteristic triphasic components of Wilm’s tumor.

Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy is not a paraneoplastic syndrome of Wilm’s tumor.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rickets

Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in rickets.

questions.text: In the ophthalmology OPD, you see a 3-year-old child with the following finding. There is no history of trauma. There is no significant family history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Neuroblastoma

This image shows periorbital ecchymoses and proptosis suggestive of metastases of neuroblastoma (a sign of orbital bone involvement).
Neuroblastomas may develop at any site in the sympathetic nervous system. Metastatic spread is common in children who are diagnosed after 1 year of age. It occurs via local invasion, hematogenous, or lymphatic routes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic because of walking difficulties. His mother says he has always walked on his toes and walks by tilting side-to-side. He also has progressive muscle weakness. There is no history of trauma, fever, or rash. On examination, calf hypertrophy with atrophied thigh muscles is noted as shown below. There is no tenderness on palpation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Duchenne muscular dystrophy

The finding of enlarged calf muscles and atrophied thigh muscles with a history of muscle weakness and waddling gait are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common hereditary neuromuscular disease. It is an X-linked recessive disorder. In DMD, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles which occurs due to muscle enlargement by the infiltration of fat. It is paradoxically weak, unlike the muscle that enlarges due to hypertrophy. Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles is the characteristic feature of DMD, whereas the other 3 conditions mentioned in the options do not have this feature.

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thalassemia

The clinical history and peripheral blood smear showing target cells and aniso-poikilocytosis, along with the Mentzer index of less than 13, are suggestive of thalassemia.

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into a-thalassemia and ẞ-thalassemia.

questions.text: By what age is the milestone shown in the image typically attained?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

12 months

The milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp, which is seen at the age of 12 months. It is identified as a mature pincer grasp as the object is secured between the opposed thumb and the tip of the index finger.

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region as shown in the image. What is the preferred drug to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Oral zinc therapy

A child with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica. It is due to zinc deficiency. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred drug.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene, SLC39A4, found on chromosome 8q24.3, which leads to zinc deficiency.

questions.text: John was brought by his mother for evaluation of a squint she noticed. On examination, the given finding was observed. Investigations revealed retinoblastoma with a germline RB1 gene mutation. The secondary malignancy most likely to develop in him is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Osteosarcoma

Children with germline RB1 mutations are at significant risk for the development of secondary malignancies, especially

- Osteosarcoma (Most common)

- Soft tissue sarcomas

- Malignant melanoma

The risk of secondary malignancies is further increased by the use of radiation therapy.

A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called ‘trilateral retinoblastoma’.

questions.text: On observing the following finding in the X-ray of a baby, what is the most likely diagnosis you would suspect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Duodenal atresia

The presence of a “double-bubble” sign on a plain abdominal radiograph is suggestive of a diagnosis of duodenal atresia. The double bubble is caused by the distension of stomach and proximal duodenum.

Duodenal atresia results from failed recanalization of the intestinal lumen during gestation. A history of polyhydramnios is present; half of the infants seen with duodenal atresia are premature. The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which is usually noted on the 1st day of life.
